_header: O mighty Mars that with thy stern light
Subjects: romances; envoys; Troy, legends of; two-line; envoys
_description: Lydgate’s Troy Book — 30117 lines in couplets, a Prologue, Five Books, Epilogue and Address to Henry V (thirteen stanzas rhyme royal) and Envoy (‘Verba auctoris’, two 8-line stanzas)

BodDig230.First Lines:
The sothfast pith to Impe it in oure þoughtOf thinges passed
                    forderked of here hewe…
BodDig230.Last Lines:
…But humbely with drawe & goo abakRequeringe hem al
                    þat is mys to amende
BodDig230.Attributed Title:
Here endith the Sege of Thebes And begyneth the Sege of Troye (f.
                        27vb)

BodDig232.First Lines:
O myghti Mars that with þi sterne lightIn armys hast the power
                    & þe myght…
BodDig232.Last Lines:
…But humblely withdrawe & go a bakRequeryng hem al
                    þat is mys to amende

BodRawC446.First Lines:
O Miȝty mars þat wiþ þi sterne liȝtIn
                    armys hast þe power & þe myȝt…
BodRawC446.Last Lines:
…But humblely with drawe & go a bakrequeryng hem al
                    þat is mys to amende

BodRawD913.First Lines:
Thy kinghly hert thy Manly excellenceReported been and þin
                    high Renoun…
BodRawD913.Last Lines:
…Her own son wer stellifiedIn þe Heven and þer
                    deified
BodRawD913.Note:
Fragment: Book I, lines 460-537, 623-702; originally part of Oxford,  Bodleian Library Rawlinson poet. 223 (SC 14714), ff. i-x and Cologny (Geneva),  Fondation Martin Bodmer Cod. Bodmer 110 [olim Harmsworth; Sotheby’s Sale, Oct. 1945, lot 1963], fragment on f.
                        3-3v ends, ‘…ffamous Argus þat couth most of all
                    / To make a ship and first þat art found’; fragment on
                        2-2v begins, ‘The tyme of yere whan þe sheen son / In
                    his spere was so fer vpron…’.

BodRawPoe144.First Lines:
Myghty Mars with thy sterne lyghteIn Armes hast þe power &
                    the myghte…
BodRawPoe144.Last Lines:
…Vnto all that shall this story seeWith benigne hert and
                    humylite

BodRawPoe223.First Lines:
To rede Bookes of thantiquitieTo fyn oonly vertue forto sue
                    …
BodRawPoe223.Last Lines:
…þus deme I fully in myn oppyniounffor of þyn age
                    thy wytt þi providence
BodRawPoe223.Note:
Fragment: Prologue from line 80; Book I, lines 1-459; originally part of
                        Oxford,  Bodleian Library Rawlinson D.913 (SC 13679), ff. 2-3v and Cologny (Geneva),  Fondation Martin Bodmer Cod. Bodmer 110 [olim Harmsworth; Sotheby’s Sale, Oct. 1945, lot 1963].
                    When the MS was rebound ca. 1985, the Lydgate fragment was separated and bound
                    separately, housed in the same conservation box as Oxford,  Bodleian Library Rawlinson poet. 223 (SC 14714).

BodDou148.First Lines:
IN þe regne and lond of ThessalyThe quhilk is now ynamed
                    Salony…
BodDou148.Last Lines:
…This litill buke lawly I betakeIt to support and þus ane
                    end I make
BodDou148.Attributed Title:
Her begynnes þe troy buke Translatit by monke of Bery (f. 1); Here
                    endis þe sege of Troye written & mendit at the Instance of ane
                    honorable chaplane sir Thomas Ewyn of Edinburgh (at the end)

OxfChrCh153.First Lines:
[ ] mote be kepte chaste & wondre [ ]and of colour surmounteth
                    euery grene…
OxfChrCh153.Last Lines:
…And shapeth ȝou no lenger to lyen herebut whyte the
                    weder is so feire and cleree
OxfChrCh153.Note:
At present the text does not have a title; however a title is recorded
                    in Kitchin (1867)
XKitchin,  G[eorge] W[illiam]. 
             Catalogus codicum mss. qui in bibliotheca Ædis Christi apud
                Oxonienses adservantur
         Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1867: ‘Digested in Latin by Guydo de Columpnis,
                    and sythes translated into Englyshe verse by J. Lydgate, Monke of Bury’.
                    The manuscript was rebound after the catalogue was made. Fragment; portions of
                    Bks. 1 and 2.

OxfExe129.First Lines:
O Mighti Mars þatþþat with þi sterne liȝt
                        [sic]In armes hast þe power and þe
                    miȝt…
OxfExe129.Last Lines:
…þis rude book lowly I be takeIt to support &
                    þus an ende I make
OxfExe129.Attributed Author: Dan John Lidgate Monke of Buri (f. 139v)
OxfExe129.Attributed Title:
And thus her endith the book of the sette of Troie translatid by Dan Iohn
                    Lidgate Monke of Buri out of Latine in to Englissh (f.
                    139v)

OxfStJohn6.First Lines:
O myghty Mars that with thy stirrne lightIn armes hast the powwer
                    and the myght…
OxfStJohn6.Last Lines:
…Bote humbely with drawe and goo a bakRequerynge hem alle
                    þat is mys to amende
OxfStJohn6.Attributed Author: Quod lidgate Monke of þe Burye (f. 133v)
OxfStJohn6.Attributed Title:
Here bygynneþ þe prolog of the seege of Troye in englischs
                    translated after the latyn compiled by Gwydo de Columpnis not word by word bote
                    after the substaunce of the lettre with certeyn addiciouns of the translatour
                    vnder correccioun of euery prudent reder The furste chapitre declareth al the
                    manere of the conquest of the goldene flees by the manly prowesse of Iason
                    acheuid by the prudent counseyl of Medea kynges doghter of Colcos (f. 1); Thus
                    endeth þe fyfþe booke Of þe seege of troye vnder þe
                    correccioun of euery prudent Reeder Quod lidgate Monke of þe Burye (f.
                        133v; Followed by ‘lenuoye’ and Verba translatoris
                        ad librum suum)

CULKk530.First Lines:
…Be cause of certane InterleueracionsOf dyuerse cercles &
                    reuolucions…
CULKk530.Last Lines:
…Thus as they hye brayes he soughthe fond a fayre pleyn wher
                    he thought

CamTCC1283.First Lines:
O Mighty mars that with thy sterne lightIn armys hast þe power
                    and the myghtAnd named art from est to occidentThe myghty lord the god
                    army…
CamTCC1283.Last Lines:
…But humibly with drawe and goo abakRequering hem all that is
                    amis to amend

BLAru99.First Lines:
O mighty mars þat with thy sterne lyghtIn Armes hast the
                    poweer & þe myghtAnd namyd art from Est tyl OccidentThe
                    myghty lord the god Armypotent…
BLAru99.Last Lines:
…Sothly quod she thyn affecciounwolde fuly turne to
                    confusyoun

BLCottAugAIV.First Lines:
O Myghty Mars that wyth thy sterne syghtIn armys hast the power
                    & þe myȝt…
BLCottAugAIV.Last Lines:
…But humblely with drawe & go a bakRequerynge hem al
                    þat is mys to amende
BLCottAugAIV.Note:
30,111 lines. Coat of arms of Sir Thomas Chaworth, apparently part of
                    original decoration, drawn inside first line initial ‘O’ (f.
                        1ra).
BLCottAugAIV.Editions:
Bergen,  Henry,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Troy Book.
             4 vols. 
             EETS
         e.s. 97 (1906); 103 (1908); 106 (1910); 126 (1935); repr.
            1973.

BLRoy18Dii.First Lines: O Mighty Mars that with thy sterne lyghtIn armes hast the powere and the myght…
BLRoy18Dii.Last Lines: …But humbly withdrawe and go abakRequyrenge hem al that ys mys amende Amen
BLRoy18Dii.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library MS Royal 18 D II.
         2015; http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Royal_MS_18_D_II.

BLRoy18Dvi.First Lines:
O miȝty Mars þat with þi sterne liȝtIn armes
                    hast þe power & þe miȝt…
BLRoy18Dvi.Last Lines:
…This rude book louly I betakeIt to support and thus an ende I
                    make
BLRoy18Dvi.Note: 28,000 lines; with colophon as noted in title.
BLRoy18Dvi.Attributed Author:
translated by John Lydgate the monk of Bury (f.
                    139v)
BLRoy18Dvi.Attributed Title:
Here endeth the book of the Sege of Troye translated by John Lydgate the
                    monk of Bury out of Latyn in to Englissh at the instaunce of the most excellent
                    & renomyd Prince king Henry þe fifte The yere of the Incarnacioun of
                    oure lord a Ml CCCC and xxti And of the reigne of the said
                    king Henry the v the viij yere (f. 139va)

GlouCath5.First Lines:
…My dulle brest that with thin hony sweteSugrest toungis of
                    Retorishiens…
GlouCath5.Last Lines:
…to be regestred worthy as of nameIn the hyhest place of
                    þe house of fame…
GlouCath5.Note:
26,426 lines when complete; this MS begins imperfectly at line 56 of the
                    Prologue, ends imperfectly in the Envoy (complete lines to line 14, and
                    fragments of lines thereafter, beg. ‘Onely…’ as last line of a
                    stanza, ending ‘…I sey’ as last line of a stanza on
                        373v), and c. 53 leaves missing at various points
                    between.
GlouCath5.Attributed Title:
Thus endeth the fyfthe boke of the Sege of Troye vndre the correccioun of
                    euery prudent Reder Quod lydgate Monke of Byrye (f. 372v)

InnerTem524.First Lines:
…[co?]mpile and after guyde make[?]can and after for his
                    sake…
InnerTem524.Last Lines:
…In euerye partie thy terrage is the samelike his fader of
                    [?sou]erand of name…

RylandsEng1.First Lines:
O Mighty mars that with thi sterne lightIn armes hast the power and
                    the myghtAnd named art from eest til occidentThe myghti lord the god
                    omnipotent…
RylandsEng1.Last Lines:
…But humbely withdrawe and goo a bakRequering hem alle
                    þat is mys to amende
RylandsEng1.Attributed Author:
daun Iohn Lydgate Monke of Bery (f. 1); Quod lidgate Monke of Burye (f.
                    172).
RylandsEng1.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the boke of the sege of Troye compiled by daun Iohn Lydgate
                    Monke of Bery atte excitacioun and steryng of the moost noble worthi and myghty
                    Prynce kyng Henry the fyfthe ffirste rehersyng the conquest of the golden flees
                    acheued by the manly prowesse of Iason vnder te correccioun of euery prudent
                    reder (f. 1); Thus endith the fifthe boke of the sege of Troye vnder the
                    correccioun of euery prudent reder Quod lidgate Monke of Burye (f.
                    172)

PierpontM876.First Lines:
…Of the explete and of the goode spedeOf this Jason that he
                    the fles hath wonBut lich in sothe as thes feyners kon…
PierpontM876.Last Lines:
…This litle boke louly I betakeyt to support and thus an end I
                    make
PierpontM876.Note:
Begins imperfectly in Book I; followed by envoy,
                    ‘Most worthie Prince of knighthod sours & well / Whos hie Renoun
                    thurgh the World dooth shine…’ (12 stanzas rhyme
                    royal).

Bodmer110.First Lines:
…And of malice and conspiracioun
                    They hym withheld both sceptre & crown…
Bodmer110.Last Lines:
…As she þat sawe by hir sorcery
                    He scapid was mony a Iupardie
                    Mony a perille and mony a grete distresse
                    And after that she fell into sekenesse
                    And hir dett yold vnto nature
                    Which escape ne may [no cr]eature
                    [  ]al þis world [       ]
                    [                                        ] king
Bodmer110.Note:
28,090 lines; begins imperfectly at I.863: ends imperfectly at V.3314 on f. 407v (lower third of leaf torn away). Originally included Oxford,  Bodleian Library Rawlinson poet. 223 (SC 14714), ff. i-x and Oxford,  Bodleian Library Rawlinson D.913 (SC 13679), ff.
                        2-3v.

HarEng752.First Lines:
…Doun ffrom hevyn ffor all his deyiteHe was ravyshede
                    thorough her bewte…
HarEng752.Last Lines:
…Born in the see Amonge the flodys kageThat was also ffor to
                    rekne hys age…
HarEng752.Note:
28,000 lines; imperfect at beginning and end; end followed by
                    catchwords, ‘ffyve and twenty yere’.
HarEng752.Facsimiles:
Lydgate,  John. 
             Troy book : manuscript, [14--]. MS Eng 752.
         Houghton Library, Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass. [digital facsimile of Harvard, Houghton Library MS Eng 752 (http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:FHCL.HOUGH:1192991)].
